instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00875: What is 820-00875? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H_CPU: What is PPBUS_G3H_CPU? PPBUS_G3H_CPU is the .
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H_CPU</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Hi I have an 00875 board with an exploded <CAPACITOR>C7222</CAPACITOR>. Removed the capacitor and others around it on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H_CPU</SIGNAL>.  

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H_CPU</SIGNAL> is still shorting to ground with them removed but I can't locate the short anywhere. Its 0.000v on diode mode.

I've tried a little voltage an some alcohol to see if anything is getting warm but no luck with that.

Any ideas?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H_CPU</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Which is the exact ohm value?
Always switch to ohm scale, for low readings.
Compare with good board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H_CPU</SIGNAL>
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H_CPU</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Oooops, is about <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>.
I was thinking about VCORE.
Now search for the same value on all big coils.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H_CPU</SIGNAL>
threads.message: The closest to 0.002ohms are L7410 @ 4.8ohms, L7420 @ 4.9ohms and L7430 @ 4.9ohms. L7210-7210 are both at 10ohms. The rest are 60ohms on a couple and Kohms or Mohms to GND

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H_CPU</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Had to edit the last post as my readings were wrong

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H_CPU</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Do you think maybe remove <CHIP>U7410</CHIP>,20,30 to see if shorted?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H_CPU</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
No, as these values are higher than <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> reading.
In your case, is safe to inject voltage on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>; should be a shorted cap.
Start with 1V, you should find the culprit with less than 2V, because of pure short.
You need powerfull (20A) lab PSU.

I hope you checked all big coils correctly!!!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H_CPU</SIGNAL>
threads.message: It's pulling 2.42a @2v but nothing seems to be heating up

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H_CPU</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Unfortunately its a short within the layers under pad 1of <CAPACITOR>C7220</CAPACITOR> :(
Not sure if this will be fixable

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H_CPU</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Took off the pad, dug down and separated the short. It had burnt the fiberglass layers under it so bad that it was shorting under the pad. I've removed the short now and i'll attempt to run trace wires in its place instead
